principles.statement: Complete formulation of shell theorem and its implications: Newton's Shell Theorem Statements: Uniform thin spherical shell: External point: field = GM/r², as if all mass at center; Internal point: zero gravitational field; Solid sphere: External point: field = GM/r²; Internal point: field = GM_inside/r². Mathematical Foundations: Geometric proof using similar triangles; Calculus proof via integration; Symmetry arguments: spherical symmetry → radial field only. Proof Methods: Geometric: cone method showing cancellation; Calculus: integrate over spherical coordinates; Vector: symmetry → field must be radial. Consequences for Solid Spheres: Uniform density sphere: Outside: g = GM/r²; Inside: g = (GM/R³)r linear with r; General sphere: g = GM_enc(r)/r². Gravitational Potential: Shell: Outside: V = -GM/r; Inside: V = -GM/R constant; Solid sphere: Outside: V = -GM/r; Inside: V = -GM(3R²-r²)/2R³. Gauss's Law for Gravity: ∮g·dA = -4πGM_enc; Analogous to Gauss's law in electrostatics; Powerful for symmetric distributions. Applications: Planetary interior modeling; Stellar structure calculations; Experimental tests of gravity; Geophysical surveys. Extensions: Non-uniform density distributions; Oblate spheroids; Multiple concentric shells; Off-center cavities.
principles.application: Apply shell theorem to calculate gravitational fields. Use symmetry arguments to simplify problems. Calculate fields inside and outside spherical masses. Determine gravitational potentials for spherical systems. Apply Gauss's Law for gravity to symmetric distributions. Solve problems involving layered spherical structures.
principles.example: Planetary gravitational field calculations. Stellar interior modeling. Laboratory mass configuration design. Geophysical anomaly interpretation. Spacecraft trajectory planning near spherical bodies. Density profile determination from gravity measurements.
principles.analogy: The shell theorem is like a gravitational 'accounting system' for spherical masses - when you're outside a spherical shell, it's as if all the mass has been consolidated into a single account at the center (point mass behavior), when you're inside the shell, all the gravitational 'debts' from different directions cancel out perfectly (zero net field), and for solid spheres, you only 'feel' the mass in accounts closer to the center than you are, with Gauss's Law acting as the balance sheet that ensures all gravitational 'accounting' follows consistent rules based on how much mass is enclosed within your position

worked_examples.title: Gravitational Field of Uniform Solid Sphere
worked_examples.problem: Derive the gravitational field both inside and outside a uniform solid sphere of mass M and radius R using the shell theorem.

step_by_step.explanation: By shell theorem, sphere behaves as point mass at center
g(r) = GM/r² for r > R
Only mass inside radius r contributes to field
Uniform density: ρ = M/(4πR³/3) = 3M/4πR³; M_enc = ρ(4πr³/3) = Mr³/R³
g(r) = GM_enc/r² = G(Mr³/R³)/r² = GMr/R³
g(r) = { GMr/R³ for r < R; GM/r² for r > R }
At r = R: inside gives GM/R², outside gives GM/R²; Fields match at boundary
Maximum at surface r = R; Inside: linear increase from center; Outside: inverse-square decrease
As you go deeper inside Earth, weight decreases linearly; At center, weightless

worked_examples.final_answer: Gravitational field: g(r) = { GMr/R³ for r < R; GM/r² for r > R }; Linear inside, inverse-square outside

worked_examples.title: Gravitational Field of Thin Spherical Shell
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the gravitational field of a thin spherical shell of mass M and radius R at points (a) outside, (b) on, and (c) inside the shell.

step_by_step.explanation: Shell theorem: field like point mass at center
g = GM/r² for r > R
Limit as r → R from outside: g = GM/R²
Shell theorem: zero gravitational field inside
g = 0 for r < R
g(r) = { 0 for r < R; GM/r² for r > R }
Field jumps from 0 to GM/R² when crossing shell; Due to infinitesimal thickness
Integrating over shell elements shows perfect cancellation inside
Explains why inside perfect spherical shell, no gravitational effects; Used in some precision experiments

worked_examples.final_answer: Gravitational field: g(r) = { 0 for r < R; GM/r² for r > R }; Discontinuous at r = R

classifications.note: Key method: Shell integration leverages spherical symmetry to reduce 3D problems to 1D integrals

principles.statement: Comprehensive integration techniques for gravitational calculations: Spherical Coordinate System: Volume element: dV = r² sinθ dr dθ dφ; Mass element: dm = ρ(r,θ,φ) dV; For spherical symmetry: dm = 4πr²ρ(r) dr. Shell Integration Method: Divide sphere into concentric shells; Each shell thickness dr, mass dm = 4πr²ρ(r) dr; Apply shell theorem to each shell; Integrate: g(R) = G/R² ∫₀ᴿ 4πr²ρ(r) dr for internal points. Gravitational Potential Calculation: V(r) = -G ∫ dm/|r-r'|; For spherical symmetry: V(r) = -G[1/r ∫₀ʳ 4πr'²ρ(r') dr' + ∫_r^ᴿ (4πr'²ρ(r')/r') dr']; Outside: V(r) = -GM/r. Non-uniform Density Distributions: Linear density: ρ(r) = ρ₀(1 - r/R); Power law: ρ(r) = ρ₀(r/R)^n; Exponential: ρ(r) = ρ₀e^(-r/a); Piecewise continuous models. Layered Structures: Multiple concentric shells with different densities; Continuity conditions at boundaries; Piecewise solutions; Geophysical applications. Numerical Integration: Simpson's rule, Gaussian quadrature; Computational methods for complex ρ(r); N-body simulations for arbitrary distributions. Special Analytical Solutions: Constant density: known solutions; Linear density: analytical integrals; Some power laws: closed forms. Gauss's Law Applications: ∮g·dA = -4πGM_enc; g(r) = -GM_enc(r)/r²; Direct field calculation without integration; Works for any spherical symmetry.

worked_examples.title: Gravitational Field of Sphere with Linear Density
worked_examples.problem: A sphere of radius R has density ρ(r) = ρ₀(1 - r/R). Find the gravitational field at all points.

step_by_step.explanation: M = ∫₀ᴿ 4πr²ρ(r) dr = 4πρ₀ ∫₀ᴿ r²(1 - r/R) dr = 4πρ₀ ∫₀ᴿ (r² - r³/R) dr
M = 4πρ₀ [r³/3 - r⁴/4R]₀ᴿ = 4πρ₀ [R³/3 - R⁴/4R] = 4πρ₀ [R³/3 - R³/4] = 4πρ₀ R³/12 = πρ₀ R³/3
g(r) = GM/r² = G(πρ₀ R³/3)/r²
M_enc(r) = ∫₀ʳ 4πr'²ρ(r') dr' = 4πρ₀ ∫₀ʳ r'²(1 - r'/R) dr' = 4πρ₀ [r'³/3 - r'⁴/4R]₀ʳ = 4πρ₀ [r³/3 - r⁴/4R]
g(r) = GM_enc(r)/r² = G(4πρ₀ [r³/3 - r⁴/4R])/r² = 4πGρ₀ [r/3 - r²/4R]
At r = R: inside gives (πGρ₀ R/3)[4 - 3] = πGρ₀ R/3; Outside gives G(πρ₀ R³/3)/R² = πGρ₀ R/3; Continuous ✓
Maximum field at r ≈ 0.67R instead of r = R; Density decreases outward

worked_examples.final_answer: g(r) = { (πGρ₀ r/3)(4 - 3r/R) for r < R; G(πρ₀ R³/3)/r² for r > R }; Total mass M = πρ₀ R³/3

image.caption: Gravitational field of sphere with linear density profile

worked_examples.title: Gravitational Potential of Uniform Sphere
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the gravitational potential everywhere for a uniform sphere of mass M and radius R.

step_by_step.explanation: V(r) = -GM/r (point mass potential)
Use V(r) = -G[1/r ∫₀ʳ 4πr'²ρ dr' + ∫_r^ᴿ (4πr'²ρ/r') dr']
ρ = M/(4πR³/3) = 3M/4πR³
∫₀ʳ 4πr'²ρ dr' = 4πρ ∫₀ʳ r'² dr' = 4πρ r³/3 = 4π(3M/4πR³) r³/3 = Mr³/R³
∫_r^ᴿ (4πr'²ρ/r') dr' = 4πρ ∫_r^ᴿ r' dr' = 4πρ (R² - r²)/2 = 4π(3M/4πR³)(R² - r²)/2 = (3M/2R³)(R² - r²)
V(r) = -G[1/r (Mr³/R³) + (3M/2R³)(R² - r²)] = -GM/R³ [r² + (3/2)(R² - r²)]
V(r) = -GM/R³ [r² + 3R²/2 - 3r²/2] = -GM/R³ [3R²/2 - r²/2] = -GM(3R² - r²)/2R³
At r = R: inside gives -GM(3R² - R²)/2R³ = -GM/R; Outside gives -GM/R; Continuous ✓
At r = 0: V(0) = -3GM/2R; Deeper than surface potential -GM/R

worked_examples.final_answer: Gravitational potential: V(r) = { -GM(3R² - r²)/2R³ for r < R; -GM/r for r > R }

worked_examples.title: Sphere with Spherical Cavity
worked_examples.problem: A uniform sphere of radius R and density ρ has a spherical cavity of radius R/4 whose center is at distance R/2 from the sphere's center. Find the gravitational field at the center of the cavity.

step_by_step.explanation: Field = field of solid sphere - field of cavity mass

step_by_step.step: Field of solid sphere at cavity center
step_by_step.explanation: For uniform sphere: g(r) = GMr/R³ inside; Distance from sphere center to cavity center: d = R/2; M_total = (4/3)πR³ρ; g_solid = GM_total d/R³ = G(4πR³ρ/3)(R/2)/R³ = (2πGρR/3)
M_cavity = (4/3)π(R/4)³ρ = (4/3)πR³ρ/64 = M_total/64
Treat cavity mass as point mass at cavity center; Distance from cavity center to itself: 0; This would give infinite field, but use shell theorem instead

step_by_step.step: Better approach: field due to missing mass
step_by_step.explanation: Cavity means mass that would be there is missing; Use shell theorem: inside uniform sphere, field depends only on interior mass

step_by_step.step: Mass that would be in cavity
step_by_step.explanation: M_missing = (4/3)π(R/4)³ρ = πρR³/48
At cavity center, missing mass would produce field = 0 (inside uniform distribution)
Draw Gaussian surface through cavity center; Only actual mass enclosed contributes

step_by_step.step: Simpler method: field is constant in small cavity
step_by_step.explanation: For small cavity far from center, field approximately uniform; Need numerical integration for exact solution
Field ≈ field of solid sphere at cavity center location; g ≈ (2πGρR/3) toward sphere center

worked_examples.final_answer: Gravitational field at cavity center approximately (2πGρR/3) toward sphere's center; Exact solution requires numerical integration

worked_examples.title: Layered Earth Model
worked_examples.problem: Earth has core radius R_c = 0.55R_earth, density ρ_c = 11000 kg/m³, and mantle density ρ_m = 4500 kg/m³. Calculate gravitational field at surface and core-mantle boundary.

step_by_step.explanation: R_earth = 6.37×10⁶ m, M_earth = 5.97×10²⁴ kg
M_total = 1.98×10²⁴ + 4.01×10²⁴ = 5.99×10²⁴ kg ≈ M_earth ✓
g_surface = GM_earth/R_earth² = (6.674×10⁻¹¹ × 5.97×10²⁴)/(6.37×10⁶)² = 9.82 m/s²
Field jumps from 3.59 to 10.87 m/s²; Due to mantle mass outside core
g = 0 (by symmetry)
Maximum field at core-mantle boundary, not surface; Explains why gravity doesn't decrease monotonically in Earth

worked_examples.final_answer: Surface: 9.82 m/s²; Core boundary: 10.87 m/s² (outside), 3.59 m/s² (inside); Discontinuity due to density jump

image.caption: Gravitational field in layered Earth model

summary: The study of gravitational fields and potentials for spherical masses represents a cornerstone of classical gravitation, providing powerful analytical tools through the shell theorem, integration methods, and Gauss's Law. These techniques enable calculation of gravitational effects for everything from uniform spheres to complex layered structures with non-uniform densities, revealing fundamental insights into planetary interiors, geophysical phenomena, and celestial mechanics. The shell theorem's elegant simplifications, combined with rigorous integration methods and the power of Gauss's Law, create a comprehensive framework for understanding and calculating gravitational behavior in spherically symmetric systems. These principles continue to find vital applications in modern science and technology, from mapping Earth's interior to planning interplanetary missions, demonstrating the enduring power and utility of classical gravitational theory in our ongoing exploration of the physical world.
